awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  How to trace glacial meltwater in the ocean using ship-portable hydrographic analysis of dissolved neon and krypton
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will build a new instrument to measure meltwater from glaciers in the ocean. Distinguishing glacier melt from sea ice, snow melt, and rain is a difficult but important task because melting glaciers threaten significant and acute consequences, including chronic flooding and sea level rise. The causes and impacts of melting glaciers are a challenge to observe and predict, because they unfold in complex and hard to reach places: beneath miles of ice, under floating ice shelves, and during the coldest times of the year.  The objective of this instrument is to increase oceanographer's capacity to measure and map glacier melt in the ocean by 300-400%, while reducing costs and providing near real-time results. This increase in measurement capacity will permit comparison of regional and seasonal changes in the glacier melt from the ice-covered land masses of Antarctica and Greenland.  The instrument will be field validated in Rhode Island coastal waters, and then it will be used to measure glacier melt near the US Palmer Station on the Antarctic Peninsula. The partnership between the University of Rhode Island and SRI international presents an important public-private partnership that will encourage the use of private-sector technology for open access research, and recruit the future workforce in environmental sensing technology by employing undergraduate ocean engineers, supporting a Masters student in the completion of their degree, and through exhibit models of glacial ice shelves and their interactions with the ocean. 
 
This award seeks to advance tracing of glacier melt in the ocean by developing a ship-portable "meltwater mass spectrometer" that measures 20Ne, 22Ne, and 184Kr dissolved in water and seawater. This advance is possible thanks to developments in gas purification, but also thanks to a new analytical capacity to measure the mass-to-charge spectrum of neon that we predict will bring new precision to the analysis. Neon is an analyte that has proven difficult to resolve in portable noble gas analyzers. It will dramatically reduce cost and expand our existing sample capacity by eliminating complicated sample storage and the lag time between sample collection in polar regions and subsequent laboratory analysis at home. We further anticipate that it will be straightforward to incorporate the MWMS technology into the SRI International underwater mass spectrometer, enabling future AUV missions to inaccessible regions, such as calving fronts and ice shelf cavities. We will test and refine the MWMS prototype by leveraging RI State funding for ship time on the R/V Endeavor and again during a full field trial in Marguerite Bay as part of the annual Palmer LTER hydrographic expedition aboard the RVIB LM Gould.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project goal was to advance measurement capabilities for determining glacial melting by developing a ship-portable "meltwater mass spectrometer" (MWMS) that measures neon (Ne) and krypton (Kr) dissolved in seawater. Glacial ice contains slightly different concentrations of these two noble gases found in seawater. Consequently, the extent of glacial meltwater entering the surrounding seawater of glaciers can be discerned by measuring small changes in concentration of these two dissolved gases.

Development of the MWMS focused primarily on measuring the isotopes of Ne and Kr found in seawater. Our approach incorporated gas purification methods and a novel approach of measuring neon concentrations using the doubly-charged neon ion (20Ne+2) at mass-to-charge ratio (m/z) 10 where mass spectra of gases in seawater typically have negligible contributions. We anticipated that this approach would bring better precision to neon analysis, an analyte proven difficult to resolve in attempts to develop portable noble gas analyzers. Our approach should reduce costs and expand the existing sampling capacity by eliminating complicated sample storage and transport for analysis. We further anticipate that it will be possible to incorporate the benchtop MWMS technology into an underwater mass spectrometer (UMS), enabling future autonomous underwater vehicle missions to inaccessible regions, such as calving fronts and ice shelf cavities.

Complementary efforts at the University of Rhode Island Graduate School of Oceanography (URI-GSO) and the University of South Florida College of Marine Science (USF-CMS) focused on optimizing prototype MWMS benchtop systems at each location. A low power gas purification system was incorporated into each MWMS that employed heated getter pills to reduce concentrations of major atmospheric gases and a cryogenic trap with liquid nitrogen (LN2) to remove a majority of water vapor. 

The URI-GSO group developed a sampling system to collect and analyze the head space of collected water samples using their benchtop MWMS to determine the sample’s dissolved gas concentrations. This was seen as the most probable method to achieve the required precision of Ne and Kr analyses to meet the goals of their Antarctic cruise scheduled during the last year of the project. Our USF-CMS effort focused on developing a complementary sampling method using membrane introduction mass spectrometry (MIMS) in which the sample water is continuously pumped past a semi-permeable membrane. Dissolved gases permeate through the membrane into the mass spectrometer (MS) vacuum system and are analyzed by the MWMS. This sampling approach is more amenable to future incorporation into a UMS for in-situ analyses.

The USF-CMS team optimized their benchtop MIMS-based MWMS for detection of 20Ne+2 at m/z 10 using deionized water with dissolved gases from different sources: (1) a gas cylinder with 0.1% Ne and Kr in nitrogen gas (N2); (2) lab air with natural concentrations of Ne and Kr; and (3) a gas cylinder with ultrapure N2. Voltages in the MS ion source were first optimized to maximize the MS signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) at m/z 10 for 20Ne+2. Then the effect of the heated getter and LN2-coldtrap stages of the gas purification system were evaluated. Finally, we optimized the ion detector voltage for S/N of the m/z 10 signal. Major outcomes and conclusions of these optimization efforts are as follows:

  • Trace levels of neon were detected using the MIMS setup with the purification system. Using m/z 10 to monitor Ne worked to significantly remove interferences from other gas species.
  • The LN2-coldtrap was essential for measurements of Ne at m/z 10 when analyzing dissolved gases in water with the MIMS probe. The getters, however, did not help in a statistically significant way, but increasing the amount of getter material might help.
  • Increasing the detector voltage from the default 900 V to 1200 V significantly increased the S/N of ion signal at m/z 10. Increasing it further to 1250 V resulted in a gain in intensity, and a corresponding increase in noise, so S/N was the same. Further voltage increase resulted in signal instability.
  • The S/N we were able to achieve with our current MIMS benchtop setup is not sufficient to discern the small changes in natural concentrations of neon and krypton required for the goals of this project. However, with the LN2-coldtrap our operating pressure in the MWMS is 10-times lower than our typical MS operating pressure. Use of a larger surface area and/or thinner membrane could allow 10-times more gas into the system, potentially improving S/N by the same factor making this approach a viable option for the future.

Shipboard vibrations encountered on research vessels often generated an analytical concern for MS instrumentation. To minimize the impact of shipboard vibrations, the USF-CMS team designed and constructed a mounting platform for the URI-GSO MWMS system that employs helical coil vibration isolation mounts. The mounting platform was delivered to URI-GSO for use with their shipboard MWMS system and was field tested at sea with very promising results.
